commentary_on_process:
I apologize for the mistake in my previous response. I misunderstood the question and calculated the population density per square mile instead of the number of people per 2 square miles. 

To solve the problem correctly, I should have divided the total population by the total area of the county to get the population density. Then, I could have multiplied the population density by 2 to get the number of people in 2 square miles. 

I will be more careful in understanding the question and double-check my calculations in the future to avoid such mistakes.
problem_text:
Context:
As of the census of 2010, there were 50,251 people, 20,065 households, and 13,721 families residing in the county.  The population density was 90 people per square mile (35/km2). There were 22,677 housing units at an average density of 40 per square mile (15/km2). The racial makeup of the county was 74.1% Race (United States Census), 19.3% Race (United States Census) or Race (United States Census), 0.7% Race (United States Census), 1.1% Race (United States Census), 0.1% Race (United States Census), 1.8% from Race (United States Census), and 3.0% from two or more races. 5.6% of the population were Race (United States Census) or Race (United States Census) of any race.

Question:
How many people are there per 2 square miles?
question_alone: How many people are there per 2 square miles?

steps.step_response:
Sure, I will break down the problem into smaller parts. 

1. Find the total population density per square mile.
2. Divide the population density per square mile by 2 to get the population density per 2 square miles.
3. Calculate the number of people in 2 square miles by multiplying the population density per 2 square miles by 2.
